question_details.query: In logged forests, is it better to retain riparian buffers or retain forested corridors to support bat populations?
What is the success rate of reintroducing captive-bred bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome (2009). Eight studies on breeding bats in captivity found that the reproductive success and survival of captive-born pups varied. In six studies, 6-100% of wild-caught female bats successfully reared young in captivity, and in two other studies, some bats born in captivity also reproduced (2053). Survival rates for captive-born pups ranged from 20% to 100% from 10 days to adulthood, as observed in seven studies. In another study, two of five captive-born pups survived and were hand-reared (2053).

question_details.query: Will training arborists to identify potential bat roosts (Action 1981) be more effective than protecting known roost trees during forest operations (Action 1982)?

relevant_summary.erroneous_summary: We found no studies that evaluated the effects on bat populations of training arborists and forestry operatives to identify potential bat roosts (Action 1981). We also found no studies that evaluated the effects on bat populations of protecting roost trees during forest operations (Action 1982).
